description.narrative: Sustainable post harvest protection of seed and grain stocks improving crop production and livelihoods in rural Timor-Leste

The majority of farmers in the target districts of Ainaro and Manufahi in Timor-Leste rely on subsistence agriculture for their livelihoods and they are effectively caught in a poverty trap. Seed access and storage dynamics play a pivotal role in this poverty trap: yields from staple crops of maize and rice decrease continuously due to the use of farm-saved seed that deteriorates in quality from season to season; meanwhile, the resultant lower production, combined with low levels of market access, reduce incomes and therefore prohibit farmers from purchasing and utilizing improved quality seed that could increase production and incomes. This is exacerbated by poor farming practices and challenging environmental factors, with climate change and extreme weather events such as the La Nina effect in 2010 having a huge negative impact on production. This situation is illustrated by high post harvest losses of seed and grain due to a lack of appropriate storage systems. There are no effective safety nets or insurance mechanisms for these subsistence farmers resulting in high food insecurity. Mercy Corps proposes a seed and grain storage program based on rigorous participatory research, taking into account cultural and economic conditions, to introduce appropriate and effective post harvest storage systems. The program is designed to be sustainable through an innovative market based approach, capacity building of farmers and extension workers, facilitating access to financial services and linking farmers with viable input and output markets to improve livelihoods. This program complements an existing 3.5 year, $1.7 million EC funded food security program implemented by Mercy Corps and partners in the two target districts with an established program team and operational base. The proposed program will fill a critical gap in the ongoing program while benefiting from cost efficiencies and established relationships with farmers and the Ministry of Agriculture.
